17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge - Oatmeal - Eggs & Pancakes
& Gravy.

Dinner: Potatoes & Salt Pork & Rice Pudding & Bread
Supper: Potatoes & meat, fruit baskets, & pie.

3 Boys age 8 to 12 - 4 Girls 4 to 14 - (Year round)

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

The dried out years 1929 to 1939,
lived on potatoes, cod fish & beans,
and sold cattle / &c. &c., and had to sell
all but one cow, as was no feed, no potatoes
or gardens of any kind. Some cars of vegetables
from Ontario but when distributed did
not give each much, but thankful for same.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Not much difference in preparation as regards meals. But more selection and choice, prices 3 or 4 times higher.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We never did rely much on purchased foods, if short tried on pancake syrup.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above; quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Bought Groceries in Bulk, in bulk, such as flour, sugar, & salt, and came into to homestead after, thrifting, for the winter.
21. Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

We never did rely much on purchased foods, only on flour and sugar.

22. Please tell us about your early experiences of buying groceries and the types of foods in other parts of the country then in Western Nevada. Products then were not as plentiful or of high quality, neither of merchandise, nor of variety. Tell us what you bought and how much it cost.

Thought Francisco in Salt Lake City, and also

Mother, father, & self, and came east.

To homeland after, thanking for its service.
Oxford
